snippet: Despite surplus grain stockpiles, malnourishment is widespread in India, where politicians are facing pressure to deal with corruption and waste in distribution programs.
abstract: India, spurred by agricultural innovation and generous farm subsidies, now grows so much food that it has a bigger grain stockpile than any country except China, yet one-fifth of its people are malnourished because of pervasive corruption, mismanagement and waste in the programs that are supposed to distribute food to the poor; nation’s failed food policies have now become a subject of intense debate with lawmakers, advocates for the poor, economists and the news media, who are increasingly calling for an overhaul.

byline.contributor: Neha Thirani contributed reporting from Mumbai and Karishma Vyas from New Delhi.

lead_paragraph: Despite surplus grain stockpiles, malnourishment is widespread in India, where politicians are facing pressure to deal with corruption and waste in distribution programs.

headline.seo: A Failed Food System in India Prompts an Intense Review
headline.main: As Grain Piles Up, India’s Poor Still Go Hungry
headline.print_headline: As Grain Piles Up, India’s Poor Still Go Hungry
